Blockchain, generative AI set to transform business, shape a bright future for Tech professionals

Guest BlogsArtificial Intelligence AIBlockchain

By Express Computer 
On Jun 15, 2023



 




 1 315 


 Share

 

By Vikram R Singh, Founder and CEO, Antier
Blockchain and generative artificial intelligence (AI) are two disruptive technologies that can truly revolutionise businesses and various professional domains across the globe. The convergence of these technologies holds immense potential in creating secure, intelligent and adaptive systems even as they are together fuelling the demand for skilled professionals and consultancies in the tech landscape. To get a nuanced perspective, we need to understand what these technologies are and how they work and complement each other.
Understanding generative AI and blockchain
Generative AI, a branch of artificial intelligence, focuses on creating new content or data that is not present in the original input. Powered by deep neural networks like variational autoencoders (VAEs), generative adversarial networks (GANs), and transformers, generative AI models learn from vast amounts of data and generate new outputs based on probabilistic models. Generative AI can be gainfully applied in content creation, data augmentation and driving innovation.
Blockchain, on the other hand, is a distributed ledger technology that enables secure and transparent transactions without intermediaries. Having revolutionised domains like finance, supply chain and identity management by offering transparency, efficiency, and enhanced security, it stores data in blocks linked by cryptographic hashes and validated through consensus mechanisms.
Complementing each other’s strengths
The integration of blockchain and generative AI unlocks numerous benefits. Blockchain technology provides control and transparency to AI models by creating an audit trail of all AI model management activities. This integration enhances accountability, governance and trust. Additionally, blockchain improves generative AI by enhancing the quality of training data, ensuring diverse and representative inputs. It strengthens cybersecurity to provide robust and efficient systems for secure transactions.
Real-world examples show the way
One notable example of how blockchain and generative AI work together is Doppl, a platform that leverages both technologies to create realistic digital avatars. Doppl utilises generative AI to create natural language interfaces that interact with users through chatbots or voice assistants. Blockchain ensures the security and privacy of user data and transactions, preventing unauthorised access or manipulation. This integration showcases the potential of these technologies in delivering personalised services while maintaining security.
Benefits, challenges and future prospects
The integration of blockchain and generative AI brings efficiency, productivity and enhanced customer experience. Smart contracts automate transactions, saving time and resources. Tailored content and recommendations based on individual preferences foster engagement and loyalty. Furthermore, this integration fuels innovation and creativity, enabling the development of new products and business models.
However, challenges like technical complexity, scalability and human impact must be addressed. The demand for skilled professionals with expertise in blockchain and generative AI is growing rapidly, creating a talent gap in the market. This gap provides opportunities for consultancies to guide businesses in adopting these technologies and addressing associated challenges.
Personalised content creation, decentralised innovation, and ethical AI development are some future scenarios enabled by the integration of these technologies. Exploring these possibilities will unlock new avenues for personalisation, collaboration and responsible use of AI technologies.
Fuelling hiring expectations
The demand for blockchain and Web3 skills is growing rapidly due to the integration of AI into the tech landscape. This surge in demand is favoring specialists with niche skillsets, like data scientists, developers, cybersecurity engineers, and blockchain developers. However, the supply of talent with these skills is limited, which has created a talent gap in the market. According to a report by KPMG, 67% of CEOs face a challenge in sourcing talent with specialised skills in emerging technologies like AI and blockchain. Moreover, the rapid evolution of these technologies requires constant upskilling and reskilling of existing talent.
Consultancies can pitch in here by helping businesses negotiate their digital transformation journey with backup support on strategy, design, implementation, testing, maintenance, change management, stakeholder engagement and regulatory compliance.
Enormous potential, possibilities galore
The integration of blockchain and generative AI is still in its infancy, but it has already shown promising results. As these technologies mature and evolve, we can expect to see more use cases and applications across various industries.
There are several potential future scenarios that can arise from the integration of blockchain and generative AI. Personalised content creation is one such scenario, enabling users to generate their own personalised content or data based on their needs. This may include creating digital avatars, music, videos, or texts through generative AI models that are stored securely on the blockchain.
Furthermore, the integration of these technologies can contribute to the advancement of ethical and responsible AI systems. Blockchain technology provides transparency, accountability and governance, which are crucial for ensuring the ethical development and use of AI. Users can track and audit the activities and outputs of generative AI models that are recorded on the blockchain, thus promoting responsible practices.
To sum it up, blockchain and generative AI are reshaping industries and driving hiring expectations. Their convergence creates systems that are secure, intelligent and adaptive. Businesses and society can benefit from increased efficiency, productivity, enhanced customer experience and innovation. However, challenges must be navigated and consultancies can play a crucial role in guiding businesses through this transformative journey. By harnessing the power of blockchain and generative AI, we can unlock new possibilities and shape a technology-driven future.

Mamsi Nkosi


FNB is running an Artificial Intelligence (AI) literacy programme aimed at equipping its workforce with skills and competencies they need to be able to use for the new world of work. The programme also equips employees to critically assess AI tools, understand their context and embedded principles, and question their design and implementation. This includes understanding the basics of what AI is, how it works, and what the strengths and limitations of the technologies are.
Financial institutions like FNB have had to reimagine ways of working and ways of engaging with their customers. We’ve had to rapidly scale up online channels used to engage customers. We’ve also had to accelerate digital transformation initiatives and embrace automation to meet complex customer needs and to drive digital operational efficiency.




We’re in the midst of an era in which emerging technologies are becoming commonplace, and ever more capable, shaking up numerous industries in the process. One of these technologies is AI, which enables computers to perform the sorts of tasks generally thought to require human intelligence, and which can “learn” and adapt, and financial services are going to be as affected by it as any other industry.
Our new reality is AI-driven, and FNB’s workforce should feel excited rather than threatened. Because instead of presenting an existential threat, AI is poised to help the Bank scale up digital channels, meet more of our customers’ evolving needs, and drive efficiency for less complex work which AI can often automate. Where AI can’t automate a task, it can often nonetheless augment people’s ability to complete it. That frees up employees to do more creative work better suited to their expertise and helps increase effectiveness throughout the organisation.
AI isn’t new, but the rate at which its changing industries is ramping up exponentially. McKinsey expects the AI industry for banking will become a trillion-dollar one in coming years. A third of that value is anticipated to come from advanced AI functions — predominantly in the risk space — with the other two-thirds stemming from traditional AI and analytics used by marketing, sales, risk, and human resource (HR) divisions.
A UBS Evidence Lab report shows that 80% of banks like ours are highly aware of the potential benefits presented by AI, and by the end of 2023, the aggregate potential cost savings for banks from Al applications is estimated at $447 billion.
While FNB continues to steer the data literacy programme to enable the organisation to “speak data”, it’s also necessary to empower our people with AI skills by ensuring a base level of AI literacy. AI helps employees become more competent by deepening their knowledge of the work they do and helps reduce the time spent doing menial tasks.
This AI literacy programme covers — among other topics — the history of AI and its potential for financial services, why organisations need an AI strategy, current AI trends and tools, aligning AI strategies with business goals, and how to use AI tools to improve your effectiveness.
It also covers how frontline staff can identify and assess the possibilities for AI in the organisation, how to justify your use of AI to top management, regulators, and their staff with performance-based evidence, and how to align AI with strategic business goals. By the end of the programme, they will understand AI use cases, how to assess and prioritise AI opportunities, how to master responsible AI principles, and the factors to consider when building or enhancing an AI infrastructure to support AI applications.
They will also understand how to create a suitable data strategy to support the organisational AI strategy, what the pre-requisites for mitigating AI failures are, and how decision intelligence connects AI, data, actions, and value creation.
This AI literacy programme will equip FNB employees with skills (e.g., how to leverage AI, data informed decision making etc.) needed to use AI technologies and applications as tools, and reimagine ways of working and ways of engaging with customers.
This programme will also enable FNB to build further and scale its AI capabilities, drive collaborative engagement, and position FNB as a leading force that is leveraging AI to continue driving the contextual banking value proposition through scaling up digital channels (e.g. AI bots, digital payment advisors and risk detection mechanisms lead to higher quality of services to a wider customer base), use AI to customize financial products and services by adding personalized features for customers, and improve customer experience by understanding and meeting their evolving needs.
Through this programme FNB will be able to accelerate the use of AI to keep up with complex, evolving, and emerging risks (including climate, cyber, financial crimes, and the like) and drive efficiency for work which AI can often automate allowing FNB to leverage human and machine capabilities optimally to drive operational and cost efficiencies and deliver personalized services.
 
By Prof. Mark Nasila, Chief Data and Analytics Officer in FNB Chief Risk Office
